Open Thread 101.75

Posted on May 17, 2018 by Scott Alexander

This is the twice-weekly hidden open thread. Post about anything you want, ask random questions, whatever. You can also talk at the SSC subreddit or the SSC Discord server.

This entry was posted in Uncategorized and tagged open. Bookmark the permalink.
← Basic Income, Not Basic Jobs: Against Hijacking Utopia
OT102: Difference Of Openion →

681 Responses to Open Thread 101.75

Reverse order
  1. Calion says:
    May 31, 2018 at 10:28 pm

    Hey! I can’t access the LiveJournal articles linked from here, for instance The Worst Argument in the World, which I know I’ve read before. Why not?

  2. sfoil says:
    May 20, 2018 at 10:25 pm

    This short story, which is sort of The Notification of Cthulhu, is being bandied around on Twitter. I liked it.

  3. Calion says:
    May 20, 2018 at 7:52 pm

    Response to MEDITATIONS ON MOLOCH

    “The more I think about it, the more I feel like this [the fish-farming story] is the core of my objection to libertarianism.”

    This wholly baffles me. This story is about the tragedy of the commons, a problem libertarianism is the solution to. Property rights fix the problems of the commons. Now you’ve got 1,000 companies each owning 1/1000 of the lake (this could be in several forms, such as a corporation, but let’s say it’s geographical (hydrographical?). Everyone would have the incentive to clean up his own area of the lake…but of course not everyone’s going to do so, for the reasons given in the example. This is why libertarianism always includes a judicial system, to adjudicate property rights disputes—in this case, the unwanted pollution coming from other fisheries. Depending on where you are on the libertarian spectrum, that’s anything from a government court system to an anarchist, organically arising court system, but there’s always some kind of court system to handle just exactly this sort of thing. No libertarian theorist I’m aware of ignores externalities of this sort, so…what’s going on with this?

    • Aapje says:
      May 21, 2018 at 4:35 am

      Diluting interests/incentives also creates issues. For example, it is a known issue that if there are more people present when someone is drowning, people tend to expect others to intervene.

    • rahien.din says:
      May 21, 2018 at 10:53 am

      Libertarianism is the solution to the tragedy of the commons.

      It would be more interesting if you would expound on this, instead.

      From my limited reading, the libertarian solution to the tragedy of the commons is not adjudication. In fact, it seems that, according to libertarians, government intervention into property rights is the exact source of the tragedy of the commons. And this problem is solved not by further government administration, but, by privatization*. This may be a caricature. CMWIW.

      * IE, someone buys the whole damn lake and then… well… administers it? Hm.

    • syrrim says:
      May 22, 2018 at 8:29 pm

      You can’t own 1/1000 of a lake. That doesn’t make any sense. You could own the land under the lake I suppose, and get mad at people for trespassing. You could own some of the water in the lake, and maybe add a chemical tracer to make sure no one can steal it – but then your water would quickly get diluted with everyone else, and flow out of the ocean pretty quickly anyways. But the lake itself is a concept at best, and not one that allows itself to easy division.

      What you could do would be set up a corporation to own the whole lake. Then people could buy shares in the corporation. If you owned shares in the corporation, you would have a say in how the lake as a whole would be treated. This would degenerate in the worst case into a democracy, which is precisely the system we were trying to avoid with this libertarian mumbo-jumbo. Dividing something up into property is supposed to let people do whatever the hell they want with their property. Instead, we have a democracy – where everyone will follow the lead of the most conservative among them, but for rare baby steps of proven progress.

      This is an argument for why britain succeeded in the early modern period – they managed to divide their agricultural land into large plots owned by one person (“enclosed field”), whereas everyone else (in europe) had large plots divided into many smaller plots that were rotated between farmers (“open field”). One of the major innovations of that era was crop rotation – basically you plant crops that fixate nitrogen (eg clover) one year, then your real crops will grow better the next year. Open fields were much slower to adopt these systems, because the individual farmer didn’t have much incentive to fixate nitrogen on a field they wouldn’t be farming the next year – open fields only adopted this system after achieving rough consensus among the farmers.

      Basically, libertarianism says: “what if we made everything an enclosed field?” – but you can’t enclose a lake.

  4. johan_larson says:
    May 20, 2018 at 4:53 am

    Anyone here know their way around video? I’m watching the series “Vietnam: The Ten Thousand Day War” on YouTube, and can’t help but notice that sometimes during the interview segments, the video looks warped, like it was shot through a pane of glass that wasn’t quite flat. Any idea what’s going on? You can see the effect quite clearly in the interview at this point:

    https://youtu.be/fNYZY-Gr6lo?t=1954

    I only see the warping during the interview segments, not when they show archival footage.

    • proyas says:
      May 20, 2018 at 9:01 am

      I don’t know how to fix that problem, but kudos to you for watching that series. Once you’re done, I recommend “Vietnam a Television History,” which is also on YouTube.

    • skef says:
      May 20, 2018 at 1:41 pm

      The algorithm is pretty clearly a form of facial image stabiliziation. The frame is also slightly zoomed in compared with other sources.

      Why? Either someone just left that setting on (it doesn’t seem to be targeted at the interviews — some archival footage with a “main face” is also stabilized) or applied it in an effort to reduce takedown requests.

      • johan_larson says:
        May 20, 2018 at 2:34 pm

        Cool. Thanks for the info.

  5. ohwhatisthis? says:
    May 19, 2018 at 9:33 pm

    Here is a good question.

    What if current tech trends continue, in its weird pattern that fits more of an exponential increase instead of a linear increase? I’m not solely talking about moores law. I’m talking about the entirety of the deep learning approaches to a wide variety of situations.

    Plenty of top AI engineers, tech engineers, and displaced workers believe its entirely possible that in 12 years its going to be possible for humans to have mostly no cognitive advantages over machines.

    So. The question is what would you say to someone born today, and then in 10 years has to seriously comprehend that he/she will have not a single topic he can do better on against a computer, except in jobs explicitly denied access to(some aspects of wars, maybe not all the kinks in precise movement have been worked out leaving a few manual labor jobs still available).

    So what would you say in 10 to 12 years to someone who is young? How would you break “maybe merge with the machines” to them? And well, with the random lurches forward, possibly even 4-5 or less?

    And before blowing this off as loon speak, remember that this is also the current bet of plenty of the largest engineering corps in AMerica, and also the current though of Elon Musk on the matter.

    • WashedOut says:
      May 19, 2018 at 10:01 pm

      I would remind them that the proper purpose of education is not to give you a job, but to develop your intellectual curiosity and give you the tools to live a meaningful life. The fact that most of the number-crunching jobs will be taken by machines shouldn’t justify any decision to stop learning how things work.

      If an employer happens to value your skills and personality enough to give you a job even during the Great Machine Takeover of 2030, then great. Otherwise, join the millions of other people like you and work out how to be meaningfully productive with your time.

      Sub-question: Does the current future outlook w.r.t. jobs and geopolitics represent a net disincentive to have children? Fertility rates in a lot of OECD countries are extremely low right now – how much of this can be attributed to future dread/pessimism?

    • Tinman says:
      May 20, 2018 at 3:08 am

      I believe that one field in which us, humans, will excel in for a long time still is adaptability. We have neuroplasticity. Most neural networks issued today are “frozen” for inference and prediction, their weights and biases do not change at all in response to incoming data. Even recurrent networks have only limited adaptability, and cannot respond to new and novel stimuli like a human can.

      I find it true that for quite a long time, even twenty years down the line, we’ll be better at most things simply because we do not require a server farm and a team of researchers to deploy on a job – just a few months at most to learn a new skill and perfect it over time. A network can be trained to be the absolute best world class at one specific task within a specific environment and using specific parameters, even be able to improvise on its own and arrive at a “good enough” solution – but present it with a completely novel situation and it will be absolutely helpless.

      It’s why truck drivers are not and won’t be a dying breed – ferrying goods is not just about driving. Yes, we’ve got good networks right now that could completely replace that part and be better at it than most drivers today. But sometimes you have to pull over and get checked over by the police. The usual neural network would completely ignore them. And sometimes your vehicle breaks down, or runs out of fuel, or you need to fill up without the convenience of automated pumps, or any number of situations that a single neural network is unable to solve even partially. Until we can replace the thousands of cooperating neural subsystems that run in our heads 24/7 with something cheaper and competent enough, we’ll still be the masters of daily life.

      So even if a bunch of different networks might be better at everything we do in five to six years, they’ll still be just a bunch of disconnected networks running on specialist hardware. We’re the jacks of all trades.

      • Lambert says:
        May 20, 2018 at 5:26 am

        You assume Autonomous trucking will look just like trucking does today, but with ll the humans replaced by computers.

        The infrastructure will change around the new technology. Trucks would have some kind of interface allowing the police to talk to someone in a call centre somewhere in the event of an issue.

        A small fleet of breakdown trucks would get vehicles working again, and better diagnostics would catch faults before they become a problem. People would be paid to refuel trucks, others to guard them at truck stops if they need to stop for any reason.
        Some of these services will be done in-house by the freight companies, some outsourced by contract, and some bought as a service each time it’s needed.

        It’s a system that would still employ humans, but only a fraction as many.

        • toastengineer says:
          May 20, 2018 at 3:43 pm

          A small fleet of breakdown trucks would get vehicles working again, and better diagnostics would catch faults before they become a problem. People would be paid to refuel trucks, others to guard them at truck stops if they need to stop for any reason.

          Why is this more efficient than just having one guy who sits in the truck and does all these things, and is also there as an emergency fallback (and scapegoat) if something goes wrong with the computer?

          • John Schilling says:
            May 20, 2018 at 5:24 pm

            Trucks have been known to travel in convoys, wherein it might be economically advantageous to have a few specialists per convoy rather than one driver per truck. Side benefit, less breakage of law-enforcement equipment.

            Likely there would be a division of the long-haul and local trucking industries, with only the latter still having a large number of human drivers.

    • proyas says:
      May 20, 2018 at 8:31 am

      “Plenty of top AI engineers, tech engineers, and displaced workers believe its entirely possible that in 12 years its going to be possible for humans to have mostly no cognitive advantages over machines.

      So. The question is what would you say to someone born today, and then in 10 years has to seriously comprehend that he/she will have not a single topic he can do better on against a computer, except in jobs explicitly denied access to(some aspects of wars, maybe not all the kinks in precise movement have been worked out leaving a few manual labor jobs still available).

      So what would you say in 10 to 12 years to someone who is young? How would you break “maybe merge with the machines” to them? And well, with the random lurches forward, possibly even 4-5 or less?”

      I think the people who are being born today (2018) are the first generation that will not have a decent shot at a traditional education-career-retirement arc. Specifically, that means that an American born in 2018, with an average IQ, to an average family, who gets average public schooling, and then some kind of average (B.A. or technical degree) higher ed degree, should expect to NOT have job security up until the traditional retirement age of 65 (2083). Very talented and/or smart humans born this year could still make it to 65 or even get rich on their own merits, but “average” folks are in real trouble. Below average people will lose their jobs even earlier.

      That being said, I’d still advise anyone born this year to try their hardest in school, and to focus on getting job skills and life skills that look like they’ll benefit them the most in the long run. Even if machines are destined to surpass humans in all types of work in your lifetime, that’s no reason to give up on your life right now. Every extra day that you are employed and contributing something to the world should be seen as a small victory for you.

      • arlie says:
        May 20, 2018 at 5:34 pm

        It looks to me as if this has already begun, and probably applies to today’s young adults, never mind today’s infants.

        I can’t prove that. And I may be misperceiving because of being born in an especially good time period, and thus seeing “normal” as “bad”, “bad” as “terrible” 😉

        At what percentile of ability/accomplishment is a young adult today unlikely to be regularly employed, likely to have huge difficulties getting a first job, and if they work at all, do so intermittently, and at the bottom end of the gig economy? It’s probably not 50%, or close to that. [Or at least I think so – those of my peers who have children are mostly well above average, so I might be wrong there too.] But is it 5%? 10% 20%? I rather doubt it’s lower than 5%.

        Bonus question – locate that person in e.g. Greece, or anywhere else with an IMF etc. enforced austerity program.

        Second bonus question – at what point is it unwise for anyone except perhaps the most brilliant to take on debt to acquire education? I.e. what % of fellow graduates need to be competing for minimum wage jobs, with little hope of anything better, for “getting a degree” to be a bad plan unless it’s essentially free?

        • proyas says:
          May 22, 2018 at 11:41 am

          Maybe by the time large numbers of people have to start seriously asking these questions, AIs will be smart enough to answer them.

          Skynet: “Though my current computational limitations and cognitive deficits preclude me from doing 85% of the jobs listed in the BLS’ List of Occupations, I can say with 99% confidence that that will have expanded to 50% by 20 years from now. My years of observing you–along with most other humans–convince me that the three jobs that would represent the optimal balance of talent utilization, satisfaction, income, and status, for you will be automated by me or a narrow AI years before you will be able to complete the training requirements. You will contribute the most to the New World Order by avoiding higher education and spending your days picking up trash and visiting old people in your neighborhood.”

          I’m only half joking about that future scenario. Moreover, I think it will be routine someday to seek guidance from AIs on all sorts of life matters, big and small, and it will be recognized that the AIs are always right.

  6. proyas says:
    May 19, 2018 at 6:44 pm

    Does smoking or stress worsen male-pattern baldness? These seem to be accepted as truisms, but from the research I’ve done (most powerfully, twin studies), it seems to be about 80% purely genetic.

    Since smoking rates were more common in the past and people had more stressful lives, was male pattern baldness worse common in, say, the 1950s than today? Has anyone seen real evidence about this?

    • Reasoner says:
      May 20, 2018 at 2:26 am

      Somewhere I read that aboriginal peoples don’t suffer from baldness, suggesting it is a product of civilization.

    • Douglas Knight says:
      May 20, 2018 at 9:03 am

      Surely stress baldness is a different pattern.

  7. proyas says:
    May 19, 2018 at 10:05 am

    Does anyone here pilot a small plane, or have a leadership position at an airport used by small planes? I have some questions about how poor weather affects small aircraft, and whether airports simply ban them from taking off if conditions are bad enough.

    • John Schilling says:
      May 19, 2018 at 11:52 am

      I fly small planes quite frequently. and the answers are “substantially” and “generally no”.

      As for the effects of weather on small planes. First is visibility. FAA regulations require special instruments, special navigational equipment, special training, and a specific approved flight plan, to fly if the straight-line visibility is less than (usually) three miles or there is >50% cloud cover within 1000′ of the ground. This is necessary both to keep airplanes from colliding with each other, and to keep pilots from becoming disoriented and literally not knowing which way is up until they hit the solid limits of down. And the 3-mile/1000-foot limit is just to set an enforceable regulatory bound; the actual safe limit can be higher or lower depending on secondary factors. JFK Jr’s final flight was legal but dangerous and foolish.

      About half of small planes and small-plane pilots have the requisite equipment and training.

      Small planes generally cannot take off or land safely if the absolute wind speed is greater than 50 knots or so, or the component of wind speed perpendicular to the runway is greater than 15 knots or so. Exact value varies from plane to plane and sometimes pilot to pilot.

      Severe turbulence, usually associated with thunderstorms, can cause structural failure of small aircraft where larger planes would “merely” see unbelted passengers suffering injuries.

      And flying through rain or clouds when the air temperature is below freezing, will cause ice accumulation which will rapidly degrade a wing’s ability to generate lift and which most small airplanes are not equipped to deal with. Some are.

      That covers the major weather-related limitations.

      As far as airports go, note that about two-thirds of the airports in the United States don’t have control towers at all, and the ones that do aren’t usually manned 24/7. There’s probably no one in position to say that it isn’t safe for you to fly, no one able to stop you from taking your plane into the air, any more than there is a traffic cop at the base of your driveway to stop you from driving on a foggy, icy road.

      If there is an on-duty air traffic controller, and the weather is below IFR minimums, they usually won’t issue a takeoff clearance without an appropriate instrument flight plan. Beyond that, they can’t make an informed decision about whether it is safe for a particular airplane to make a particular flight. They don’t know each make and model of aircraft’s crosswind limitation or anti-icing equipment; they don’t know the turbulence or icing conditions along the pilot’s route of flight – in part because the pilot will likely change his route based on reports of turbulence and icing by other pilots.

      They will pass on warnings regarding hazardous conditions, often with an explicit “are you sure you want to do this” level of urgency. If there are traffic controllers at all, which there usually aren’t. There’s always a pilot (so far…), and the pilot has the ultimate responsibility for determining whether a flight can be conducted safely.

      • proyas says:
        May 19, 2018 at 12:56 pm

        John,

        Thank you. I’ll confess: the reason I’m asking about this is because I’m thinking about the plausibility of flying cars and of the next best thing, which is autonomous small planes and helicopters. Everyone focuses on the technical aspect of whether or not flying cars can be built, but no one thinks about how much practical use they would actually be. For that, lessons from small plane pilots like yourself are invaluable.

        I suspect that, even if flying cars existed, and even if they could fly as well as good human pilots, they would refuse to take to the air during poor weather to protect human life. I suspect they’d be programmed to be very cautious, as autonomous cars are today. This would of course severely undermine their real-world utility, as you wouldn’t be able to commute from your country house on the lake to your job at a downtown 100 miles away if there were always a 10% chance your flying car will refuse to take off thanks to bad weather.

        Furthermore, even if a flying car could journey through bad weather safely, it might refuse to take off because the projected turbulence would be so bad that its passengers would be vomiting everywhere.

        I believe these same problems will apply to autonomous small planes and small helicopters, which I think are much more attainable than flying cars. The future vision where you depend on some type of small, flying vehicle to get you to work each day breaks down.

        What do you think?

        • John Schilling says:
          May 19, 2018 at 1:54 pm

          An autonomous small aircraft is almost certainly going to be able to cope with low visibility by default, because most of the ways we have for autonomous systems to orient themselves and navigate don’t depend on vision in the first place. And once you take visibility out of the equation, the problem may become more tractable.

          Or not, and local climate is going to be a big determinant there. You can’t fly if there are thunderstorms close at hand, or a storm front between you and your destination. Is that a crippling limitation? Southern California, no. Central Texas, maybe yes. You can’t fly on a freezing, cloudy day. Crippling limitation half the year in Minnesota, not so much in Arizona. 50-knot winds are a regular afternoon thing in Mojave, but fairly rare just across the coastal range in Los Angeles.

          So, presuming we can get autonomous air vehicles to an acceptable level of safety for manned operation, and we’re still a long ways from that, they could probably serve as a primary means of transportation in some areas but not everywhere. Southern California looks pretty good if you can take visibility out of the equation; the big weather hassle here is the marine layer of fog and low clouds that shows up right around the morning rush hour. Other than that, you’d probably be able to get 98% or better dispatch reliability.

        • Aapje says:
          May 19, 2018 at 2:16 pm

          @proyas

          Flying cars prototypes have existed, but they seem to be both shitty planes and shitty cars.

          Anyway, a Dutch company claims to be making the first actual production run of a roadworthy gyrocopter. €300k for the base model.

          • proyas says:
            May 19, 2018 at 3:24 pm

            @Aapje

            Yes, I know that flying cars already exist. However, because of the major engineering compromises inherent in their designs (they are “shitty planes and shitty cars” as you say), I think we may be better off building a lot of autonomous small planes and helicopters plus an expanded network of small airports and helipads. You would take an autonomous Uber car to the nearest small airport, switch to an autonomous small plane or helicopter, have it fly you to an airport or helipad near your destination, and then switch to another autonomous Uber car to take you the rest of the way.

          • John Schilling says:
            May 19, 2018 at 4:02 pm

            What proyas says.

            The problem with past “flying cars” is that they insisted on being actual cars, i.e. roadworthy ground vehicles with reasonable performance and safety. That’s exceedingly difficult to manage, given the conflicting requirements of air vs. ground transportation, and why are you even doing that?

            The fantasy of finding yourself stuck in traffic and saying, “ha ha, losers, I’m going to fly over you all”, sure, very appealing, but if you really can fly, you start flying at the start of your trip, you don’t wait until you’re stuck in traffic.

            The bit where you can’t make your “flying car” VTOL just yet and so still need a runway, annoying, but of all the possible solutions to that particular last-mile problem, driving the entire airplane away from the airport is the least practical. We’ve got Uber, we’ve got folding bicycles and electric scooters and God forbid even Segways, pick one and make do until the VTOL system reaches the market.

            That weather might sometimes mean you can’t fly, sure, but mostly you’ll know when you check the forecast in the morning whether that’s going to be an issue. And if you can afford a flying car, you’re probably a two-car family at least, so take the one designed for the road that day.

            Airplanes, helicopters, etc, are for flying and should remain so.

        • Lambert says:
          May 19, 2018 at 5:43 pm

          I suspect that if you managed to make an autonomous human-rated aircraft, it would be much more technically skillful at flying than any human. i.e. flying in a storm is far easier for a machine than, say avoiding geese.

          Passive-unstable aircraft like the Typhoon demonstrate that a fly-by-wire system can achieve super-human reaction times, allowing it to operate an aircraft that no human could directly control.

          The other benefit is that the computers would be hard-wired straight into the plane sensors and actuators. Human pilots are limited by the number of controls they can operate at once.
          I foresee fully autonomous flying vehicles having a lot more control surfaces than existing planes, or variable wing geometry, or thrust vectoring, or independent maneuvering thrusters or something.

        • hapablap says:
          May 19, 2018 at 11:08 pm

          When you say small planes and small helicopters, there are currently fully autonomous versions of both. The Diamond DA-42 airplane has been converted to autonomous and did a flight in 2015 (not available to buy as autonomous). Aurora Flight Sciences has created a conversion kit for helicopters to make them autonomous for military supply drops, controlled with just a tablet. Conceivably in the civilian world you could go on an IFR flight plan that was all automated with the navigation decisions made for you by the system.

          But weather decisions would be hard to automate unless you made the things so overly cautious that they were not useful for commuting. There is plenty of legal room to push the weather way beyond what your aircraft can handle, so the legal limits won’t do you much good. Icing is an issue, turbulence can be but requires a lot of local knowledge that you’d never see in weather reports. Assuming your aircraft can land in zero visibility makes things a bit easier since you won’t need diversion options.

          As a daily commuter there will still be plenty of things to worry about in these autonomous aircraft even if they technically fly better than a human. The human will still need to do a preflight inspection (15-30 minutes), make the weather decision both for legality and safety, check for navigation service outages or airport facility closures, decide how much fuel to put in, make sure the aircraft is within weight and C of G limits. If there’s something broken on the aircraft (which happens all the time) the human will need to decide whether to defer or get an engineer over or fly it to maintenance or what. If you are going off airport, you need to find out the legality of the flight, permission for the landing site. You’ll have to worry about pissing off your neighbors with noise both for landing and take-off which might involve some legal hassles.

          • John Schilling says:
            May 20, 2018 at 5:34 pm

            When you say small planes and small helicopters, there are currently fully autonomous versions of both.

            For definitions of “autonomous” that do not involve carrying people or flying over cities, which is a crippling limitation for this proposed application. This doesn’t seem likely to change any time in the next 5-10 years, for legitimate safety reasons.

  8. Nancy Lebovitz says:
    May 19, 2018 at 9:42 am

    https://www.alexanderschool.edu.au/single-post/2018/05/19/Are-orthotics-useful

    There’s no solid evidence for orthotics for most of the conditions they’re prescribed for. They are good for rheumatoid arthritis and for high arches.

    For other conditions, improved coordination can be a more effective solution.

    Personally, I’ve only gotten plantar fasciitis from a chi gung exercise called swimming dragon, which I solved by not doing swimming dragon. However, I didn’t have the problem with the exercise when I was younger, so maybe I should take a serious look at how I’m doing it.

    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9IOX50Y7dso

    https://www.amazon.com/Swimming-Dragon-Chinese-Fitness-Beautiful/dp/0882680633

    Also, I cleared up flat feet for a while by doing an exercise about the relationship between hips and ankles from _Running with the Whole Body. I need to get back to that.

    https://www.amazon.com/Running-Whole-Body-30-Day-Program/dp/1556432267

    • Reasoner says:
      May 20, 2018 at 2:22 am

      Personally, I’ve only gotten plantar fasciitis from a chi gung exercise called swimming dragon, which I solved by not doing swimming dragon. However, I didn’t have the problem with the exercise when I was younger, so maybe I should take a serious look at how I’m doing it.

      Aches and pains tend to become more common with age. I’d suggest massaging each calf using the knee of the opposite leg, and rolling a ball beneath each foot in order to massage it. That cleared my plantar fasciitis up in a few weeks.

    • knownastron says:
      May 20, 2018 at 8:18 am

      What do you mean by “cleared up flat feet”?

      Do you remember the name of the exercise? So I can Google it without buying the book?

      I’ve suffered from foot problems for years now so I take an active interest in this topic.

      • Nancy Lebovitz says:
        May 20, 2018 at 8:48 am

        I could feel that I had arches.

        There is no e-book and my copy isn’t handy– there’s a chapter called something like connecting the hips to the feet.

        The general idea is that arches are actually strongly influenced by hips– if you roll you foot from side to side, the arch goes up and down, and that movement comes from the hips.

        I don’t know where you live, but the cheapest copy at amazon is $2, so about $6 with postage. The exercise takes about an hour, and it might be a worthwhile gamble.

        • knownastron says:
          May 20, 2018 at 3:06 pm

          That’s interesting.

          Reminds me of something I read about Steph Curry. The trainers realized that he had weak hips and after strengthening them his ankle injuries went way down.

          I’ll buy the book! Thanks!

          • Nancy Lebovitz says:
            May 21, 2018 at 2:43 am

            You’re welcome.

            Could you post about whether it works for you or not?

            There’s an early chapter about just walking and increasing awareness, and I wasn’t able to use that (though trying it more times might have been good). A friend wasn’t able to manage it, either. I still got value from skipping to an exercise in the middle.

  9. ohwhatisthis? says:

  10. Nancy Lebovitz says:
    May 19, 2018 at 8:48 am

    I’ve wondered how much differences in intelligence are affected by whether a culture is welcoming to intelligence.

    Steven Barnes has talked about his mother telling him that if white people knew how smart he was, they’d kill him. She was obviously factually wrong, but she wasn’t crazy.

    Sometimes white people attack black people for being successful– https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tulsa_race_riot1921, successful black neighborhood destroyed by white rioters

    A more recent example of black people being attacked for being successful, though this one is verbal.

    There’s also a claim that black children who do well at school subjects get attacked for acting white– I believe this happens, though I don’t have a feeling for how pervasive it is.

    You might be thinking, but what about Jews? There might be a difference that Jews cannot protect themselves from anti-Semitism by pretending to be stupid.

    I find it plausible that how well people do on IQ tests and in life could be affected by how welcome intelligence is by the people around them, both in their community and outside it.

    • dndnrsn says:
      May 19, 2018 at 9:03 am

      Something I mentioned above is that the “environmental” side of things is related to others helping you – which is to some extent affected by their genes; what if particular elements in an environment prevent them from helping you?

      Example: let’s say reading to your kids is good for their IQ. For the purposes of the example, let’s say it’s not chicken-and-egg (reading to your kids is just a sign that you have good IQ, so they will too) but higher-IQ parents are more likely to read to their kids. If reading to your kids was discouraged for some reason, culturally, then even if a parent can do that, they won’t. (And if they’re not allowed to learn to read…) Or if your parents being able to get as good an education as they can will help your IQ, outside limits on the education they can get will hurt your IQ.

      Also, with regard to Jews, consider the difference in stereotyping between the far more assimilated urban Jews in Western Europe and some parts of Eastern Europe (eg, Budapest) and the far less assimilated, poorer rural Jews in most parts of Eastern Europe. This didn’t stop Eastern European Gentile peasants from having fairly typical “they have all the money!” stereotypes, but tbh, in late-19th-early-20th-century rural Eastern Europe, you didn’t have to have all that much to get thought of as rich (and if someone isn’t rich, you can just say they’re hiding the money). But for Western Europe – there’s a reason Nazi propaganda promoted the idea that poor rural Jews in Eastern Europe were what they were really like, and the assimilated and urbane Jews of Western Europe were just a mask. Late 19th/early 20th century biologically-based anti-Semitism (as opposed to death-of-Christ based religious or medieval blood libel-based anti-Judaism) had to paint a picture of Jews as simultaneously superior (in string-pulling ability, at least) and inferior.

      This is all self-reinforcing: keep a group from getting an education, at a minimum they’re uneducated; if this actually hurts their IQ, they’re dumber than they would be (as opposed to people who are uneducated but clearly sharp). Then the oppressive majority says “look, they’re uneducated/dumb!” – likewise, force people into their own pocket communities, then point out that they keep to themselves, mighty fishy, eh?

    • albatross11 says:
      May 21, 2018 at 6:39 am

      Nancy:

      This is an interesting question. One thing I think we can probably say is that American culture generally is quite friendly to intelligence relative to a lot of historical cultures. Specifically, we assume everyone ought to go to school and learn to read and do math and such, literacy is assumed as a basic part of being a full member of society, intellectual accomplishments are often pretty celebrated, etc. There’s not really a widespread social belief/movement that the lower classes should be kept from education so they don’t try to rise above their station, or that women/peasants/factory workers don’t need any education. There’s plenty of anti-intellectualism and some worship of ignorance in some places[1], but that’s a bit different animal. And I guess there’s still some level of getting bullied for being smart that happens–I don’t know if that’s more common in black communities than white ones. I’ve heard people talk about black kids getting hassled by other black kids for “acting white,” but since I got bullied in my 95% white grade school for being smart (and obnoxiously letting other students know I was smarter than they were, but I didn’t really see it that way at the time), I’m not entirely convinced that this is just something that happens among black kids.

      How would we figure this out? There are middle-class black communities with a lot of college-educated parents, so we could look to see what the gap looks like in those communities. But we have two confounders:

      a. The average IQ of the parents will be higher there, and since IQ is partly heritable, their kids will also be smarter than average.

      b. It’s hard to say whether any anti-intellectual trends in black culture (assuming there are some that explain some of the gap) are still present in those communities.

      I expect someone’s looked into this, but I don’t know the literature well enough to know.

      [1] Nor is this restricted to the red tribe. I’ve seen way too many people basically express pride that they’ve never read some offensive book or studied some offensive academic subject they know is Problematic.

      • Nancy Lebovitz says:
        May 21, 2018 at 7:30 am

        Albatross11:

        “One thing I think we can probably say is that American culture generally is quite friendly to intelligence relative to a lot of historical cultures. ”

        I think we can say this, and we can also say that American culture is not as friendly to intelligence as a really pro-intelligence culture would be.

        from what I can tell, America has become more pro-intelligence in my lifetime. From what I can remember, in the 60s, being very intelligent was neither properly masculine nor properly feminine. In other words, no one was really supposed to be very intelligent.

        Things shifted when it was clear there was a lot of money to be made in IT.

        If you want to see what favoring a trait looks like, consider America and athleticism.

        For a long time, people have been saying that intelligence isn’t the same thing as wisdom, even when no one said that intelligence is the all purpose mental tool. I admit I haven’t heard that as much lately.

        It’s rather rare to hear that fitness isn’t the same thing as health.

        Obviously, there are people who cultivate and use their intelligence anyway– it can be a pretty strong drive– but I wonder how much has been and is lost from people who decide it’s safer to not appear especially intelligent. Or who haven’t had as much chance to cultivate their intelligence because the tools aren’t available to them.

        This is something that might not show up on IQ tests.

        And wouldn’t be easy to change if it’s a strong feature of the culture.

    I mean, OK, but wouldn’t be more direct to just poke around a bit under numpy.random?

        May 20, 2018 at 3:04 pm

        A “humanize” post-processing pass would probably give you a big improvement in listenability; just randomize the start times and volume of each note a tiny bit.

  12. thepenforests says:
    May 18, 2018 at 8:05 pm

    Question for the military folks here (might have been asked before on a previous open thread, surely been asked many times before on the internet in general, would be happy with either off-the-cuff answers or links to more in-depth answers):

    What’s the actual ramp-up capability of the various world military powers in the event of a serious war in the modern day?

    In other words, to what extent would each country be “stuck with what they had” if they were forced to go to war, and to what extent would they be able to produce new weapons/tanks/aircraft/ships/etc in a short enough time and in large enough quantity to make a difference?

    I ask because it seems obvious to me that we’re now far away from a WWII-type scenario, where countries were able to rapidly start mass-producing (frankly) insane numbers of new weapons platforms over a very short time, iterating designs on practically a year-by-year basis. (Honestly, from a modern perspective, I’m always kind of amazed at what various countries were able to achieve over the mere six-year course of WWII; I remember seeing some graphs of military production during WWII that were pretty mindblowing – anyone have any links?)

    I imagine this kind of ramp-up was possible in WWII largely because weapons back then were still (relatively) primitive. In other words, designing a better plane in the 40’s wasn’t that complicated – it was more a matter of strapping a better engine to the airframe and adding a few more bolts, or something like that. Something a single mechanic or engineer could maybe understand on their own. Whereas today you need 80 PhD’s and a couple hundred engineers just to design the exact shape of the aileron, or whatever. And I gather that you can’t get away with doing less than that now – the modern battlefield is just too demanding. Creating a less-advanced plane wouldn’t just result in something that’s a bit less effective in the air – it’d result in something that’d be shot down immediately, and would almost be worse than useless (I exaggerate, probably? But I don’t know how much?)

    In other words, it seems like modern weapons platforms are so advanced/costly/time-consuming-to-build that it would be really really hard for any country to do a WWII-style ramp-up in production. I can’t imagine this isn’t true, to some degree – somehow, in the event of a modern day war, I don’t see us designing, prototyping, and building a successor to the F-35 in a year or two, building a thousand of them, and then scrapping it and starting production on a new plane in another year or two. That kind of thing just doesn’t seem possible anymore. And my impression is that modern military strategy is to some extent based on this assumption, that we have to have large standing armies with large numbers of advanced weapons platforms *already* in existence, simply because we couldn’t create them fast enough to make a difference if we really needed them.

    Okay, so modern-day war probably wouldn’t look like WWII. But I don’t know *how* far we are from such a scenario. Sure, we built 27 new carriers over the course of WWII, and it takes us a decade or so to build a new Ford-class carrier right now, but how much quicker could we do it now if we really really needed to? Five years? Three? And what’s our parallel capability – are we really limited to only building a couple carriers at a time right now, or could we do more if we had the funding/desire? And if we can’t right *now*, how quickly could we expand our shipyards to be able to produce more ships at once in a time of need?

    And forget numbers, what about generations? I know that fighters progressed rapidly during WWII, pretty much to the point where a couple-year-old fighter was out of date by the end of the war (I think?). These days, new fighters pretty much take decades to develop, and we’re still using fighters from the 70’s. Could we rush the design of completely new fighters, or would we be stuck producing more of what we had (F-18’s/F-22’s/F-35’s)? Or could we do something in between, kind of upgrading the design of new fighters as we build them?

    Basically I’m asking what a war between major powers in modern times would *actually* look like, assuming it lasted for more than a year or so. How much would the production capacity of the country (and the ability to switch to a “war economy”) matter? I want to say “not that much, unless the war went on for a long, long time”, but I honestly don’t know.

    Of course, I imagine the answer to my question would depend on what aspect of the military we’re talking about – obviously some things would be easier to start mass-producing than others. In my mind, the progression from easiest-to-ramp-up to hardest-to-ramp-up would go something like munitions/artillery/missiles -> tanks -> helicopters -> fighters -> regular naval ships -> aircraft carriers, but I could be way off on that.

    I’d love to hear everyone’s thoughts on the matter; I find this kind of thing fascinating.

    • albatross11 says:
      May 18, 2018 at 10:09 pm

      I’m not any kind of military person, but I think we’ve had war pushing development of weapons since WW2–in Korea and Vietnam, and more recently in Afghanistan and Iraq and Syria (and Yemen and Niger and wherever else). We could look at the rate of weapons production and rollout there as a sort of lower-bound.

      It seems like a WW2-scale war would be between great powers, and would be constantly in danger of going nuclear.

    • Watchman says:
      May 19, 2018 at 1:57 am

      Assuming no nuclear i think the only country that might manage a prolonged war against the major world power, the US, might be China. I’m pretty certain that everyone else’s military would be obliterated pretty rapidly should the US commit it’s full strength (remember Russia’s military is about the size of France and Germany’s combined, and a lot less advanced; North Korea’s is actually smaller than South Korea’s in every measure other than manpower). So it’s quite a specific question…

    • proyas says:
      May 19, 2018 at 11:54 am

      “And I gather that you can’t get away with doing less than that now – the modern battlefield is just too demanding. Creating a less-advanced plane wouldn’t just result in something that’s a bit less effective in the air – it’d result in something that’d be shot down immediately, and would almost be worse than useless (I exaggerate, probably? But I don’t know how much?)”
      Yes, but in your WWIII scenario, presumably all sides would be suffering from approximately equal levels of attrition, so you might be able to put simpler, lower-tech weapons back into service because much of the enemy’s advanced prewar stuff will have been destroyed.

      Also, you shouldn’t pick WWII as an example of how fast military technology can progress. During that era, there were a lot of “low-hanging fruits” so to speak that were ready to be picked with more funding at military research labs. For everything I know about aerospace, that field has almost hit a technological plateau, where eking out linear improvement requires exponentially more money with each step.

      In a WWIII scenario, I think the ability to ramp up production would, unsurprisingly, be inversely related to the complexity of the piece of equipment. Small arms, bullets, uniforms, and simple vehicles like jeeps and lightly armored APCs wouldn’t be a problem to make.

      Making new warships would be hugely problematic, not only because construction times are longer, but because there are far fewer shipyards today than in the 1940s. The U.S. has the world’s best Navy, but there are only about ten shipyards in America that can build or do extensive work on its warships. Long-range missiles, nuclear weapons, and ultra-quiet long-endurance attack subs would also make it impossible to protect big ships under construction. Even keeping warplane and tank factories might be impossible given their sizes.

      In WWIII, I think we’re sure to see the different sides recalling a lot of mothballed equipment to service (think of America’s “reserve fleet” https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Navy_reserve_fleets and of its aircraft boneyard in Tucson https://www.abc15.com/news/state/the-boneyard-a-secret-airplane-graveyard-in-tucson-arizona), doing some upgrades to get them closer to modern standards, and sending them into battle. Something like a Lend-Lease Program could happen again, with combatant countries “borrowing” or reclaiming weapons that they donated to old allies that have stayed out of WWIII. Outright purchases of newly made weapons from noncombatant countries would also help fill the gap (Brazil, Sweden, South Africa, and Singapore come to mind as usually neutral countries that have strong defense sectors).

      Military leaders would of course be cognizant of this problem and would learn to use their best equipment are carefully as possible, so you’d see F-16s doing attack missions in place of F-35s.

      I think the assumption for a long time has been that a Third World War would rapidly go nuclear, in which case both sides would have their industrial bases and much of the military forces very badly damaged, forcing the inevitable use of lower-tech equipment. Look at the sharp dropoff in the quality and sophistication of German and Japanese weapons in the last year of WWII and then realize that participants in WWIII will probably reach that point much earlier in the fighting.

      “Basically I’m asking what a war between major powers in modern times would *actually* look like, assuming it lasted for more than a year or so. ”

      I think George Orwell made an accurate insight in “1984” that, once a country reaches a “continental” scale, it becomes effectively impossible for anyone else to conquer. And interestingly, the three great powers in his book–Oceania, Eurasia, and Eastasia–still exist in reduced form as America, Russia, and China. And the way their WWIII played out is probably how ours would: the sides would practically destroy each other with nuclear weapons early on, and in the aftermath, would realize they lacked the ability (military resources + willpower) to overrun their enemies with conventional forces and subjugate their people in the way the Allies did to the Axis countries in WWII. The front lines would stabilize, and either peace would be agreed to or a de facto peace would come to be.

    • proyas says:
      May 19, 2018 at 12:27 pm

      A passage you might like:

      ‘[By 1945] Japanese industry had ground to a halt for lack of raw materials. Hashimoto Yukio was working on a project to manufacture a special type of aluminum. “The quality of material used for airplanes had declined to the lowest level. The collection of pots and pans (which were melted down to make planes) was totally inadequate to meet our needs.” When his team began to salvage materials from downed B-29 bombers he realized the odds which Japan was up against. “I had thought that since Japan was under such duress, the quality of American materials would naturally have suffered as well. But the components were analyzed met the normal standards, and the surface of the propellers shone brightly like silver. I won’t forget the chill I felt at the strength of American production capabilities.”‘
      –The Taste of War, page 309

    • sharper13 says:
      May 19, 2018 at 7:24 pm

      Don’t confuse the current bureaucratic procurement process with what can happen in wartime, when people are given orders to just get it done and nobody stands in their way.

      Even in limited wars like the recent conflicts in the middle east there have been quick projects for improvements reacting to the enemy’s tactics. From armies using drones (commercial and special built) to armoring humvees and tanks to defeat new threats, when people are dying, it’s a lot easier to cut through the paperwork. When the enemy started using commercial off-the-shelf drones, the marines quickly re-purposed jamming equipment the size of two trucks to stop it. Within a few months, they brought in newly built equipment better designed to neutralize commercial enemy drones while leading the way.

      New weapons design doesn’t take that long to create and procure, except when the bureaucracy takes over. The DOD is actually working on that, figuring out ways to speed up the process, as its a recognized problem.

      Secondarily, others have already alluded to the purpose of mothball fleets of ships and planes. They’re essentially designed to be the quicker-to-reactivate force while spinning up/converting the factories.

      • Aapje says:
        May 20, 2018 at 12:56 am

        Actually using the equipment in combat also gives far better and quicker feedback than just testing it.

    • John Schilling says:
      May 20, 2018 at 5:21 pm

      Looking at the few examples we have of modern wars, the actual high-intensity conflict part (if any) tends to be over pretty quick. Six Days, an extended holiday, two months on the far side of the world, forty days and forty nights, five days. I think that covers the big ones. So even the most optimistic hopes for shortening development or production cycles by getting the bureaucrats out of the way, are I think going to run afoul of hard physical realities. Modern weapons, even the non-nuclear sort, are effective enough that there won’t be anything to shoot at by the time the weapons you ordered on the first day of the war roll off the production line.

      Occupations, counterinsurgency campaigns, and containments of defeated enemies that you’re not going to conquer, can drag on a bit, but they also don’t generally require much in the way of new technology, or even greater numbers of classic weapons than you used to defeat the enemy in high-intensity combat in the first place. There are occasional exceptions, e.g. IED jammers in Iraq and Afghanistan, but they aren’t going to dominate the equation.

      • dndnrsn says:
        May 20, 2018 at 7:55 pm

        You have the Yom Kippur war linked twice; presumably you double-copied and your third link is meant to be to something else?

        A pause for rearming that historically happened with technology that’s somewhat antiquated today: WWI at the end of 1914 into 1915. Losses of men and materiel plus expenditure of ammunition and so on were much higher than expected. It brought down a British government. Probably not even near to the way it would be were it to happen today.

        • albatross11 says:
          May 20, 2018 at 8:20 pm

          Should the Falklands War be in the list somewhere?

          • John Schilling says:
            May 20, 2018 at 9:01 pm

            That was the one that was mistakenly overwritten with a second Yom Kippur reference.

    • bean says:
      May 21, 2018 at 6:03 am

      Sorry, I missed this over the weekend.
      A war between major powers that lasts more than a few days is pretty implausible. Either it will escalate, and we’ll briefly play Tom Lehrer songs, or it will be resolved before that happens. And yes, you’re pretty much right that we can’t develop stuff quickly. There’s been an ongoing shift in complexity. It was starting to affect ships during WWII (most ships were pre-war designs, and those that weren’t were designed around pre-war combat systems) and has spread to airplanes today. So no, there’s no chance we could knock together an F-35 successor in a year or even 10. The cycle time on a software upgrade to a military airplane is a year or two. A lot of it is that we’re approaching more and more closely the platonic ideal, while not having giant leaps in technology to apply to our work.

      And what’s our parallel capability – are we really limited to only building a couple carriers at a time right now, or could we do more if we had the funding/desire? And if we can’t right *now*, how quickly could we expand our shipyards to be able to produce more ships at once in a time of need?

      For carriers in particular, not quickly. I believe the limiting rate is about 1/3 years, if we’re fully utilizing the drydock at Newport News, and there’s no easy way around that bottleneck. We built some of the dinosaur-burning supercarriers elsewhere, but I think mostly at yards that are now closed. It would be a bit easier to speed up the production of other stuff, but there are still likely to be bottlenecks keeping us to maybe 2x current rate without a lot of expense and some delay.

  13. entobat says:
    May 18, 2018 at 1:18 pm

    I’ve been thinking about the classic “brain damage disproves souls” argument, and I don’t think it makes sense.

    In brief: if we’re ensoulified, then all the typical brain-y things we think about vis-a-vis intelligence—speaking English, knowing animal names, knowing your friends’ faces, playing bridge—are actually run by the soul. But then why can I scrape out one part of your brain and stop you from knowing my face, when you still know what a hammer is? Why can I damage one part of your brain and stop you from speaking English well, but you’re still a brilliant artist?

    I think the model living behind the argument is that the brain and the soul are two parallel potential causes of me knowing how my mom’s voice sounds. It’s improbable that they are both doing it, and we can poke my brain in a way that stops me from knowing my mom’s voice, so it must not be the soul doing it.

    I don’t think this is a very good argument. Why do the brain and the soul have to be in parallel? Imagine we really do have a soul, and the brain is simply the wiring that hooks up the soul to the physical reality. You destroyed the wiring that connects the face-recognizing part of my brain to my soul? Shucks, I don’t know what my friends look like anymore. You damaged the language-wiring portion? I have aphasia.

    This model of souls is still stupid—it’s still not doing any conceptual heavy lifting—but I don’t think the above argument is really doing anything beyond pointing that out.

    • Urstoff says:
      May 18, 2018 at 1:42 pm

      The fact that “the soul” isn’t doing any explanatory work (conceptual heavy lifting, as you say) make it an unnecessary element to postulate. Subtract all the things the brain does, and there’s nothing left for the sould to do.

      • entobat says:
        May 18, 2018 at 4:57 pm

        Sure. I’m saying I remember this argument being framed as “souls are actually a worse fit for the observed data than not-souls” instead of “Occam’s razor means no souls”.

        • Urstoff says:
          May 18, 2018 at 9:28 pm

          Sure; that would, of course, depend on what causal model of the soul one is working with. Unfortunately, most people who invoke souls as explanatory don’t have much of an explicit causal model to speak of. Most invocations of souls are far too underspecified to be useful.

      • Michael_druggan says:
        May 18, 2018 at 5:23 pm

        Yeah souls will only be reasonable if somehow we had a proof that naturalistic explanations could never solve the hard problem of consciousness, This seems to be what Penrose believes except his “soul” comes from speculative quantum mechanics rather than the supernatural.

        • Aron Wall says:
          May 19, 2018 at 11:49 am

          For some definitions of “naturalistic”, Chalmer’s p-zombie argument is pretty close to the proof you are looking for. Although I don’t think Cartesian dualism is the only possible alternative.

      • Orpheus says:
        May 19, 2018 at 12:15 am

        What about consciousness? I know that I am conscious, but how can I tell that other people are not just complex reflex arcs who never feel anything, just pretend to be feeling things? Wouldn’t your argument apply equally well to the assumption that other people are conscious?

        • Protagoras says:
          May 19, 2018 at 12:20 am

          This has been discussed before. Despite the claims of various endarkeners, we have an increasingly good understanding of what’s involved in consciousness, and based on that it is not a mere assumption that other people have it. Consciousness is only a great mystery to those who pretend to understand it much better than they actually do, and who as a result insist that perfectly adequate accounts are unsatisfactory because they fail to satisfy misguided intuitions.

          • Orpheus says:
            May 19, 2018 at 8:42 am

            Could you direct me to these discussions?

          • Protagoras says:
            May 19, 2018 at 10:56 am

            There have been many. They usually haven’t been very productive; this certainly isn’t an area where SSC discussion has produced anything that goes beyond what you’d find in the scholarship (various Dennett, e.g. Sweet Dreams, any of the David Lewis papers on philosophy of mind, or on the side of the endarkeners Chalmers is probably the most prominent).

    • Protagoras says:
      May 18, 2018 at 1:45 pm

      Of course the switching station model has been endlessly discussed (it was Descartes model, and the objection you discuss was raised by Princess Elisabeth in her letters to Descartes). Briefly, we would expect different effects from disrupting the thinking apparatus itself than from disrupting the means of the thinking apparatus interacting with the outside world. What we observe resembles the former. This is certainly not conclusive evidence; all sorts of confounders could lead to results other than what we would expect, and so could potentially lead to a situation which resembles what we would expect from the former while really being the latter. But the overwhemingly more likely explanation is that what we observe resembles the former because it is the former.

    • skef says:
      May 18, 2018 at 2:26 pm

      Lesion studies can lead to more specific results than a simple loss of function. There are cases in which a patient has been still able to do X and to do Y but has significantly lower performance on tasks that involve a combination of X and Y. A material explanation of this problem in terms of a lesion is straightforward: the channel directly between the regions responsible for X and for Y has been damaged, leaving either no channel or a much slower alternate channel.

      Explanations in terms of a soul, along the lines your analysis suggests, make less sense. In that model the different areas of the brain presumably “pre-process” and communicate specific types of information to the soul, which is the unified entity responsible for higher-level cognition, the locus of subjective experience, and so forth. “Unified” is a key term here — the intuition is not that there is a face-recognition mini-soul, and a higher-level reasoning mini-soul, and an emotional impression mini-soul, and so forth, but a single entity that explains and reflects the (apparent?) unity of cognition. Evidence that areas of the brain serve as communication channels counts against that picture and for, at best, a mini-soul model.

      • entobat says:
        May 18, 2018 at 7:56 pm

        This is a cool result. Thanks for sharing.

    • Michael_druggan says:
      May 18, 2018 at 5:12 pm

      One response I’ve heard to this is that if you damage a TV’s antenna it disrupts the show but that doesn’t mean the show is being produced in the antenna. So maybe our brains aren’t producing conscious experience but just channeling it. I’m not really convinced but it makes more sense than the model you mention.

      • Protagoras says:
        May 18, 2018 at 5:22 pm

        Again, this is only plausible on the most cursory examination. If damaging this part of the antenna made the show less funny, and damaging that part of the antenna got rid of all the male characters, and damaging that other bit over there made it show the end of a program before the beginning, well, there still might be a very strange story on how broadcasting works in that situation, but more likely we’d be talking about a world where antennas really do produce the shows. It’s because damage to antennas doesn’t do any of those things, but instead just corrupts the image and sound quality without changing anything else, that we could pretty easily have figured out an antenna was just a transmission mechanism even if we didn’t know the details of how television works. As I mentioned above, and as Skef also said with slightly more detail, damage to brains does precisely the sort of things we’d expect it to do if the brains were doing the thinking; it doesn’t do the sort of things we’d expect it to do if brains were like antennas.

  14. LittleChanges says:
    May 18, 2018 at 1:10 pm

    Any SSC-reader tips on finding decent psychotherapy — or in lieu, recommendation for providers in the Boston area?

  15. j1000000 says:
    May 18, 2018 at 10:57 am

    I’m looking for book recommendations on a particular subject — descriptive books on how modern economies work, not just supply and demand/opportunity cost/etc economics. Even if it’s polemical, I want more “this is how society functions on a daily basis, how farmers and investors and the Fed are tied together.” Any suggestions appreciated.

    • sharper13 says:
      May 18, 2018 at 11:21 am

      “Economics in One Lesson” by Hazlit is what I’d consider the standard introductory summary to economics which mostly covers what you describe. It’s a little dated, but still relevant. You probably want an edition published after 1978.

      • j1000000 says:
        May 18, 2018 at 11:33 am

        I read that about a decade ago and remember thinking it got pretty repetitive after that first Bastiat summary, but maybe I should revisit it now. I’m looking for something like — what are corporate bonds/how does the stock market fund companies, alongside “I, Pencil” stuff. Maybe that doesn’t exist? Not sure.

          May 18, 2018 at 12:59 pm

      • rahien.din says:
        May 18, 2018 at 1:30 pm

        I would second both this recommendation but also j1000000’s description of it as a bit repetitive.

        It’s easy to find a .pdf of it via the google

    • SamChevre says:
      May 18, 2018 at 11:57 am

      Not exactly what you are looking for–nothing about market structure, for example–but one very helpful book is John Kenneth Galbraith The New Industrial State; it’s the only general-reader economics book that I know of that focuses on the role of large companies.

  16. Watchman says:
    May 18, 2018 at 10:39 am

    There has been a lot of discussion around rational attitudes towards eating meat on open threads and the last link thread. I’ve read this with interest but something hasn’t felt right. I think I may have now identified the issue, which is there appears to be a meta-argument that has either passed me by or has not been had.

    This relates to the normal measure those trying to assess the utilitarian approach to meat eating take, which is to try and assess relative suffering, hence the wonderful philosophical question of whether the suffering of one cow outweighs that of x chickens. On face value this seems reasonable – we can accept suffering lowers utility of an action as a moral judgement, regardless of whether we agree. There is however a very large but here, which is the issue that suffering here appears to be at best a subjective judgement each observer makes, or, potentially, a way of presenting dogma as a utilitarian choice.

    My reason for this hypothesis is simply that I don’t know of a way of measuring suffering, or even a unit in which it could be measured. A neuroscientist might want to correct me on this, but I am pretty certain that suffering is a mental state not a physical one (as with any mental state it can have physical effects of course but I doubt these are diagnostically consistent), which is defined as in operation by the person experiencing that state. Crucially, if my definition is correct then suffering is an individual experience and likely to be therefore understood and demonstrated differently by different people.

    Note that this could apply to actual physical effects such as pain, which can cause a contrasting range of reactions from suffering to joy, and an accompanying range of physical reactions. However, pain has a recognised mechanism in place which means we understand how it is caused even if we are unsure on the reaction. Pain is therefore at least theoretically measurable even if the requirement for an MRI makes this highly impractical to apply. Pain is a real and measurable biological process. Suffering is subjective and perhaps even socially constructed although I’ll leave that as a suggestion rather than seek to examine the claim.

    Herein lies my problem though, which is that with some animal cruelty and some human volunteers we could establish baselines for comparing the experience of pain in different species, a proposal to keep any ethics committee fully employed if nothing else. There is no way to establish an equivalent baseline for suffering though. Indeed, there is no way to understand if a different species actually suffers, since all we can do is work of physical cues. Anthromorphising the experience of a battery-farmed chicken to see it as suffering is to make an unsupported assertion that you would suffer in these circumstances so therefore the same thing holds for a creature with a totally different wiring of its brain, mental understanding of the world and life experience (insofar as a chicken can have such a thing – a question for any poultry scientists around…). Any assessment of animal suffering is therefore going to be prejudiced by our own assumptions as there is no way to produce a viable neutral indicator against which we could test them. At the moment the only qualifier on our assumptions of suffering is the views of other humans, which might lead us to a consensus, but a consensus based on no actual evidence. So, I contend, we cannot measure animal suffering in any way unbiased enough of our own assumptions to make this a meaningful measure.

    I will confess here that this conclusion matches my view on this debate: I believe utility is only applicable to humans, and animals have to be assessed in that light (animal suffering still lowers human utility though). Hopefully my analysis here is more robust than simply being an opportunity to assert my viewpoint though.

    • ohwhatisthis? says:
      May 18, 2018 at 11:34 am

      In the wild, animals don’t typically run into cramped locations covered in their own shit and piss. Something gives me an inkling the current farming system is off.

      • Le Maistre Chat says:

        This. Factory farming is wrong.
        Is it wrong to eat meat at all? I think that’s a religious issue.

      • John Schilling says:
        May 18, 2018 at 12:31 pm

        Wild animals frequently run into (or build) cramped locations free of predators, leaving only when they need to find food and/or dispose of waste. If the wilderness contained warrens with steady food supplies and waste-removal systems comparable to modern farms, this would be a much stronger argument.

        • albatross11 says:
          May 18, 2018 at 10:02 pm

          I don’t think the inherent humanity and kindness of nature toward wild animals is going to make the argument you want against human cruelty to animals.

          • John Schilling says:
            May 18, 2018 at 10:54 pm

            Nature is not inherently humane and kind to wild animals. That’s what humans are for. Even human farmers, at least by comparison to nature.

      • Well... says:
        May 18, 2018 at 6:25 pm

        You already know what I’m going to say…

        In the wild, plants and fungi don’t typically reproduce so that their most delicious and nutritious parts are impractically oversized and so they are more resistant to the diseases that would make them yield less of these parts. They don’t typically sow themselves in neat convenient rows and cover themselves with soaps and other foreign chemicals. They don’t typically get cut down tens of acres at a time. They don’t typically get tossed into boiling water or run through giant shredding machines or placed inside of ovens.

        Guess I agree about the current farming system, though my conclusions about it are probably different.

      • Watchman says:
        May 18, 2018 at 10:17 pm

        In the wild there are no chickens (they’re a human creation). And the chickens in factory farms have never experienced the wild. I think this another case of assumptions about how animals process their experiences, in this case assuming the wild is a default for animals with no experience of it. This might be more justifiable in that we can release factory-farmed animals into the wild and see how they react, although a reaction to an unknown experience cannot prove suffering before the experience was undertaken. But it is lazy thinking to make a case on this assumption without justifying the assumption.RAM

        To be clear here, I’m with you and Le Maistre Chat in my moral view of factory farming, which I think is also of limited utility to humans (less meat of better quality is optimal). I’m concerned that the level of argument in defence of this position (or against it) tends to be an assertion of an assumption or an opinion, which is not getting anyone anywhere.

        • Well... says:
          May 19, 2018 at 5:01 am

          That’s exactly what I believe also. Well put.

    • Kaura says:
      May 18, 2018 at 7:38 pm

      The assertion of animal suffering is not unsupported by evidence, though. It’s inconclusive and at least currently impossible to verify with the kind of measurements you describe, definitely, but I don’t think that rules out all attempts at sensible inference. Anthropomorphising is completely fair if there are reasons to assume that the target in fact probably should resemble humans in some ways that are relevant to the question at hand, e.g. if suffering seems to make evolutionary sense as an internal motivational state in many kinds of animals with observable properties typically associated with it in humans. You don’t need to be able to directly measure hedonic states to care about animals, and I don’t think it’s entirely justified to dismiss assessments based on other grounds as arbitrary prejudice.

      • Watchman says:
        May 19, 2018 at 1:06 am

        Fair point. I think my issue was with the framing of suffering as something that could be used to determine the most ethical/utilitarian approach towards determining diet. It seems reasonable to make an inference though, although in good faith this surely has to be stated to be such. It also probably doesn’t work as a way of engaging with someone who already had drawn their own conflicting inference, as we lack any mechanism to start to determine which inference might be the better hypothesis. I’m perfectly happy with the idea that an understanding that there might be suffering should inform a moral position. I just can’t see how this provides a basis for discussion about the appropriate actions to take, as there’s no common currency for discussion. I will happily withdraw any suggestion that to base a decision on suffering is arbitrary, although I’d like to keep the prejudice: I find it hard to believe anyone reaches an inference on a matter such as eating meat without being influenced by their own existing beliefs and experience. Indeed, I’m quite certain my position in the wider debate derives from prejudices derived from growing up in a rural environment surrounded by rather stupid and tasty animals.

    • citizensearth says:
      May 19, 2018 at 11:30 pm

      You appear to treat ‘mental’ phenomena as non-physical, which I think creates a problem for your logic.

      Indeed, there is no way to understand if a different species actually suffers, since all we can do is work of physical cues.

      So try substituting different ‘species’ for different ‘person’. For animals or other humans, we always go off physical queues, because humans don’t access the ‘first-person’ thoughts of other humans directly. We can’t even verify they have ‘first-person’ thoughts at all, or, to use a popular but vague and undefinable term, ‘consciousness’. This is called the ‘problem of other minds’ or ‘other minds problem’ in philosophy, and if you treat suffering as non-physical, there’s no logical solution to it imho (it horrifies me to hear someone say p-zombie suffering doesn’t matter, because everyone else is effectively a p-zombie in consistent dualist reasoning). I guess you could say a person can talk and describe their experience, but why would we consider a person/animal screaming and running away from a danger unconvincing but talking about it somehow convincing? If humans suffer then animals clearly do too, the question is primarly how much do we prioritize consideration of that suffering into our actions. We might also broaden that to questions of quality of life, and perhaps notions of freedom.

      Eating on the hand, well, unless I get cremated, I and most people I know will likely get eaten by other species when we die (worms, bacteria etc). I don’t think the eating is the issue, so much as how organisms live and die. Personally I think the best solution for this would be for us to invest in vat-grown meats, and solve the problem, at least as far as what humans eat is concerned, once and for all.

      • Watchman says:
        May 20, 2018 at 6:38 am

        Pretty certain I clearly stated human suffering was subjective. I’m not interested in considering whether other people’s experiences are real or not, as I believe they are for convenience as I have to interact with them. I have to believe this though as proof is no more possible than with animals.

        Incidentally, running and screaming are markers for fear and pain, as a first estimation. In mammals at least both would be measurable. There’s no reason to assume suffering, a subjective and assumed human experience, applies as well without using our own experiences as analogies.

  17. albatross11 says:
    May 18, 2018 at 7:53 am

    Another article related to the Harris/Klein kerfluffle

    And once again, the problem is that he wants us to consider the social consequences of our words and be super careful about speculation before there is strong evidence, but only on one side of the issue. This amounts to putting a thumb on the scales of societal truth-finding mechanism that just barely work in the best of times. It also amounts to keeping the public and decisionmakers ignorant of relevant facts of reality.

    • J Mann says:
      May 18, 2018 at 9:22 am
